input_args.examples: {'document_id': ['0004589', '0004589', '0005867', '0000738'], 'document_source': ['GARD', 'GARD', 'GARD', 'GARD'], 'document_url': ['https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/3701/orofaciodigital-syndrome-2', 'https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/3701/orofaciodigital-syndrome-2', 'https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/8503/squamous-cell-carcinoma-of-the-head-and-neck', 'https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/5926/birdshot-chorioretinopathy'], 'category': [None, None, None, None], 'umls_cui': ['C2931889|C0039082', 'C2931889|C0039082', 'C1168401|C0007097', 'C1853959'], 'umls_semantic_types': ['T047', 'T047', 'T191', 'T047'], 'umls_semantic_group': ['Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders'], 'synonyms': ['OFD2|OFD syndrome 2|Oral-facial-digital syndrome type 2|Mohr syndrome|Orofaciodigital syndrome II|Orofaciodigital syndromes', 'OFD2|OFD syndrome 2|Oral-facial-digital syndrome type 2|Mohr syndrome|Orofaciodigital syndrome II|Orofaciodigital syndromes', 'Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma|HNSCC|Carcinoma, squamous cell of head and neck', 'BSCR|Multiple small, cream-colored lesions, symmetrically scattered mainly around the optic disk|Birdshot chorioretinitis|Birdshot retinochoroiditis|Birdshot retinochoroidopathy'], 'question_id': ['0004589-4', '0004589-5', '0005867-1', '0000738-1'], 'question_focus': ['Orofaciodigital syndrome 2', 'Orofaciodigital syndrome 2', 'Squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck', 'Birdshot chorioretinopathy'], 'question_type': ['inheritance', 'treatment', 'information', 'information'], 'question': ['Is Orofaciodigital syndrome 2 inherited ?', 'What are the treatments for Orofaciodigital syndrome 2 ?', 'What is (are) Squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck ?', 'What is (are) Birdshot chorioretinopathy ?'], 'answer': ['How is orofaciodigital syndrome type 2 inherited? Orofaciodigital syndrome type 2 is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means that an individual needs to inherit two mutated (changed) copies of the gene-one from each parent-in order to have the condition.', 'What treatment is available for orofaciodigital syndrome type 2? Treatment is dependent on the symptoms. For example, reconstructive surgery might be performed to correct oral, facial, and/or finger and toe abnormalities.', 'Cancers that are known collectively as head and neck cancers usually begin in the squamous cells that line the moist, mucosal surfaces inside the head and neck (for example, inside the mouth, the nose, and the throat). These squamous cell cancers are often referred to as squamous cell carcinomas of the head and neck. At least 75 % of head and neck cancers are caused by tobacco and alcohol use. Infection with cancer-causing types of human papillomavirus (HPV), especially HPV-16, is a risk factor for some types of head and neck cancers. The symptoms of head and neck cancers may include a lump or a sore that does not heal, a sore throat that does not go away, difficulty in swallowing, and a change or hoarseness in the voice. Treatment for head and neck cancer can include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or a combination of treatments.', 'Birdshot chorioretinopathy is an eye condition in which painless, light-colored spots develop on the retina.  These spots are scattered in a "birdshot" pattern.  The effects of this condition on vision are quite variable; some individuals\' vision is only mildly affected, whereas others experience a significant decline in vision, the appearance of floaters (small specks that appear in one\'s line of sight), night blindness, and other vision problems.  Symptoms typically begin around middle age; Caucasians are affected more than individuals of other ethnicities.  The cause of birdshot chorioretinopathy is currently unknown, but it is suspected to be an autoimmune disease.  Treatment may include medications that aim to regulate the body\'s immune response.']}
